answers.author: Thomas Fountaine
answers.text:
The Borough of State College provides all employees with a transit pass.  A parking is also provided.  We have the ability to track transit use through the contract with the transit authority.  Employees that utilize transit must obtain a pass from the transit business office.  The Borough pays a flat fee annually to the transit authority regardless of ridership by employees.  The annual fee is set based on previous ridership data.  We do not have a written policy on this.

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Our transit department has the policy below on the books. We do not track the number of employees who use the benefit for commuting or errands. Transit is a City department, not a separate authority, so implementing the benefit doesn't require a great deal of policy or contracts. There is another, more formal agreement with the University of Virginia to allow students and staff to ride free. I usually walk to work but like the bus benefit during bad weather or if I have an unexpected meeting across town. 
"B.   City and CAT ID Cards: All new Full-time City of Charlottesville employees are issued a City ID card.  All City of Charlottesville employees may ride CAT buses fare-FREE by showing their City ID card.  CAT issues an ID card that is used to “punch in” and “punch out” of the CAT electronic time clock and access the facilities at Avon St. and the Downtown Transit Station."

answers.text:
The City of Oklahoma City provides paid parking or a bus pass to most full-time employees that work in the immediate downtown campus of City offices.  Employees that work in locations that offer free parking are excluded.  The paid parking or bus pass benefit is reviewed each year and included as part of the labor agreement.  They cannot be shared.
For further information, please contact:
Jeanna Jordan
jeanna.jordan@okc.gov
405.297.3396
